body: I was wondering how do we want to handle the top level column index on these cases? In the univariate case, we currently assign "Coverage" to it. Do we want to change the interface to use feature names in all cases?

> Do we want to change the interface to use feature names in all cases?

I thought about this and have no 100% answer. My trouble is that in the univariate case, for common user journeys, there are no column names - e.g., if the input is a `pd.Series`. If the column is then called "0", it might be confusing for users.

Do you have any good suggestions?

I see how it could be confusing in the univariate case if there is no column names. But i wonder if it is difficult in the multivariate case to know which column belongs to which feature. I wonder if it it bad design to use the names of features only on the multivariate case, even though this would complicate the tests?

Alternatively, what about adding a keyword feature before the feature name e.g. if the column name is '0', we could use 'feature_0' and so on to make it more clear and consistent in both uni and multivariate cases?

I looked into documentation and come up with the following list of forecasters where predict_interval still needs to be refactored:

- [ ] MultiplexForecaster
- [ ] EnsembleForecaster
- [ ] TransformedTargetForecaster
- [ ] BaseGridSearch
- [x] ColumnEnsembleForecaster https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/pull/2081

I am a little bit unsure about the Reducers as they don't have a "scitype-y" tag.

> I am a little bit unsure about the Reducers as they don't have a "scitype-y" tag.

Hm, that seems like an oversight - although I'm not sure off the top of my head which value would be correct.

> I looked into documentation and come up with the following list of forecasters where predict_interval still needs to be refactored:

Thanks! I added that list to the issue description.

>Alternatively, what about adding a keyword feature before the feature name e.g. if the column name is '0', we could use 'feature_0' and so on to make it more clear and consistent in both uni and multivariate cases?

I've been thinking about this, perhaps a `RangeIndex` for columns is the best solution? That would keep '0', but not as a string.

I lean this direction now since I've been running into case distinctions in the `predict_etc` defaults, and I also noticed, what do we do if there is a variable called `"Coverage"` or `"Quantiles"` etc? That would spell the same trouble as the `"ds"` reserved variable name in prophet...

> I looked into documentation and come up with the following list of forecasters where predict_interval still needs to be refactored:

Is `ForecastingPipeline` missing?

I think that the first step would be to update all the univariate forecasters to have RangeIndex as the top level index, as well as edit respective tests in one PR.

After I can change PR to account for this change https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/pull/2041 

Nest step will be implementing quantile and intervals in  the other multivariate forecasters

>I think that the first step would be to update all the univariate forecasters to have RangeIndex as the top level index, as well as edit respective tests in one PR.

So, `RangeIndex` if there is/are no variable name(s), correct?
Would this be with internal conversion from `numpy` to internal `pd.DataFrame`, which would create `RangeIndex` cols by default?

Yes, makes sense to me - I would suggest a separate PR just for this, if you want to make the change.

issue.title: [BUG] ForecastingPipeline does not implement `predict_quantiles` or `predict_interval`

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
**Describe the bug**
When using a `ForecastingPipeline`, the checks for prediction interval need to be based on the final forecaster in the pipeline but currently this does not seem to be the case.

**To Reproduce**
```python
from sktime.datasets import load_longley
from sktime.forecasting.theta import ThetaForecaster
from sktime.forecasting.compose import ForecastingPipeline
from sktime.transformations.series.impute import Imputer
from sktime.forecasting.base import ForecastingHorizon
from sktime.forecasting.model_selection import temporal_train_test_split

y, X = load_longley()
y_train, _, X_train, X_test = temporal_train_test_split(y, X)
fh = ForecastingHorizon(X_test.index, is_relative=False)

# This works ----
forecaster = ThetaForecaster()
forecaster.fit(y_train, X_train, fh=fh)
forecaster.predict_quantiles(X=X_test, alpha=[0.05, 0.5, 0.95])

# But this does not ----
pipe = ForecastingPipeline(steps=[
    ("imputer", Imputer()),
    ("forecaster", ThetaForecaster())])
pipe.fit(y_train, X_train, fh=fh)
pipe.predict_quantiles(X=X_test, alpha=[0.05, 0.5, 0.95])
```

```python
RuntimeError: ForecastingPipeline does not implement probabilistic forecasting, but "capability:pred_int" flag has been set to True incorrectly. This is likely a bug, please report, and/or set the flag to False.
```

**Expected behavior**
Would have expected the `ForecastingPipeline` to look at the underlying `ThetaForcester` for capability and run to completion i.e. produce the same results as `forecaster.predict_quantiles(X=X_test, alpha=[0.05, 0.5, 0.95])`. 


**Versions**
<details>
System:
    python: 3.7.13 (default, Mar 16 2022, 17:37:17)  [GCC 7.5.0]
executable: /usr/bin/python3
   machine: Linux-5.4.144+-x86_64-with-Ubuntu-18.04-bionic

Python dependencies:
          pip: 21.1.3
   setuptools: 57.4.0
      sklearn: 1.0.2
       sktime: 0.11.0
  statsmodels: 0.13.2
        numpy: 1.21.5
        scipy: 1.4.1
       pandas: 1.3.5
   matplotlib: 3.2.2
       joblib: 1.1.0
        numba: 0.55.1
     pmdarima: None
      tsfresh: None
</details>

issue.title: [ENH] adding compatibility with probabilistic and hierarchical forecasts to `ForecastingPipeline` and `TransformedTargetForecaster`

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
This PR adds compatibility of `ForecastingPipeline` and `TransformedTargetForecaster` with:
* the probabilistic forecasting interface points `predict_interval` etc
* hierarchical and panel inputs for hierarchical, panel, global forecasting

This PR alsp:
* fixes `_has_capability` for the case where tags can be dynamic (such as here)
* adds test parameters to `ForecastingPipeline` and `TransformedTargetForecaster` that cover the probabilistic case
* fixes one missing argument of `_predict_proba` in the extension template.
* adds a `_transform` to the `ForecastingPipeline`.
* fixes a broken error message in the `test_pred_int_tag` test
* fixes `BaseForecaster` which was missing the `marginal` arg in `predict_proba`.

Addresses parts of #2088, #2243, #2313.

Contains the fixes in https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/pull/2322 which are necessary for tests not to break, since `_has_capability` has changed and that uncovers the issues with `inverse_transform` etc in #2322.

issue.title: [ENH] `MultiplexForecaster` compatibility with multivariate, probabilistic and hierarchical forecasting

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
This PR partially resolves #1364 and #2088, it enables `MultiplexForecaster` to work with multivariate, hierarchical, and/or probabilistic forecasters.

This is achieved by replacing manual loopthrough with:

* tag cloning
* delegation via the general `_DelegatedForecaster` (which includes the probabilistic methods and will also pick up any future method that is added)

This PR also contains:
* docstring improvements in the `_HeterogeneousMetaEstimator`
* a docstring fix, added missing default value for parameter `deep` in `get_params` throughout the code base

This PR depends on:
* refactor and fixes to `update_predict` in https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/pull/2466
